node.text: New Year’s Eve would have been the perfect occasion for a decorative headpiece for day and evening, currently on view in #InPursuitofFashion. They echo the modernity and opulence found in apparel of the 1920s. // Hat, Lasdon (American, active 1900–37), 1920s; promised gift of Sandy Schreier. Photo © Nicholas Alan Cope #TheMet #CostumeInstitute

Introduced into Western fashion through 18th century trade routes bringing goods from India, Kashmiri shawls—and their European imitations—were a highly fashionable way to stay warm. The shawls were woven of colorful, fine wool and remained stylish accessories of luxury through the 1860s. // Shawl, Indian, ca.1865; Gift of Miss F. L. Schepp, 1955 (C.I.55.16.3); dressed with Ensemble, French, 1865–67; Gift of Mrs. Alfred Poor, 1958 (C.I.58.4.4a–e). #TheMet #CostumeInstitute

Trim the tree or wear the dress! This coat from @maisonmargiela was featured in this year’s spring exhibition, #MetCamp. Happy Holidays from The Costume Institute! // Coat, Martin Margiela (Belgian, born 1957) for Maison Margiela (French, founded 1988), Artisanal fall/winter 2007–8; courtesy of Maison Margiela Archives. Photo © Johnny Dufort, 2019 #TheMet #CostumeInstitute

Remembering Emanuel Ungaro, who passed away at the age of 86. From bright colors to mixed prints as represented in the #CostumeInstitute’s collection, Ungaro’s designs captured the youthful and changing spirit of the 1960s through the 80s. // Left to right: Ensembles, Emanuel Ungaro (French, 1933–2019), ca. 1971; Gifts of Joanne T. Cummings, 1976 (1976.360.34a–e, 1976.360.35, 1976.360.37a–g).

Fashion in motion: The organza on this Balenciaga evening jacket has a striking holographic or moiré effect when it moves and overlaps. The fabric provides an unexpected texture and structure, and attention to such detail is part of the legacy of couturier Cristobal Balenciaga. // Evening Ensemble, Cristobal Balenciaga (Spanish, Guetaria, San Sebastian 1895–1972 Javea) for House of Balenciaga (French, founded 1937), spring/summer 1950; Gift of Mrs. G. Macculloch Miller, 1975 (1975.389.1a–c). #TheMet #CostumeInstitute #CollectionsCare

Sweater Weather: Mohair sweaters have been popular in London since the 1950s, but in the ‘70s Vivienne Westwood made her own version with a looser knit and bolder, asymmetrical color blocks that was decidedly different from the predictable stripes and colors of past decades. // Sweater, Vivienne Westwood (British, born 1941), Malcolm McLaren (British, London 1946–2010 Switzerland) for Seditionaries (British, 1976–1980); 1976–80; Gift of Barbara and Gregory Reynolds, 1985 (1985.375.7). #TheMet #CostumeInstitute

Paul Poiret was ahead of his time when in 1911, he expanded his fashion business to include two additional houses: Parfums de Rosine, dedicated to fragrances, and Atelier Martine, a school and showroom for the decorative arts. Georges Lepape’s illustration for this paper fan demonstrates a savvy union of marketing interests. Though the clothing and interior depicted on the front are products of Poiret’s fashion and furnishing lines, the back advertises a range of Rosine fragrances. A small sticker identifies “Mea Culpa” as the scent chosen to perfume this promotional item. See this on view #InPursuitofFashion. // Promotional Fan, Georges Lepape (French, 1887–1971) and Paul Poiret (French, 1879–1944) for Parfums de Rosine (French, active 1911–30), ca. 1919; promised gift of Sandy Schreier. #TheMet #CostumeInstitute

Holiday outfit research: During Mainbocher’s career, he exhibited innovative ideas, such as the strapless dress, feminine details like gigot sleeves, ruffles and trains, and the use of men's shirting. This ruby red cocktail ensemble featuring a petal-tiered skirt and wrap jacket is an excellent example of Mainbocher's later work. // Cocktail Ensemble, Mainbocher (American, 1890–1976), ca. 1955; Brooklyn Museum Costume Collection at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, Gift of the Brooklyn Museum, 2009; Gift of Mrs. Ian B. MacDonald, 1965 (2009.300.383a, b). #TheMet #CostumeInstitute

This 1902–04 silk velvet evening coat by Huet and Chéruit (later known as simply Chéruit) recently came out of our storage for a research appointment. Madame Chéruit was among the foremost couturiers of her generation, along with other major French fashion houses of the late 19th century such as Paquin, Doucet, and Worth. Swipe through to see the textured, metallic embroidery details. // Evening Wrap, Huet and Cheruit, 1902–4; Purchase, Gift of Mrs. Lawrence Tibbett, 1958 (C.I.58.42.3) #TheMet #CostumeInstitute

The Message is the Medium: These lively designs are conversant with the zeitgeist, yet draw on historical dress, art, and popular culture through references that include biography, humor, and quotation. Just as the garments express the distinct personalities of their makers, their assemblage here reveals the individuality and eye of their collector, Sandy Schreier. Though the pieces span a period of 60 years, they are united in their embrace of fashion for its storytelling ability. #TheMet #CostumeInstitute #InPursuitofFashion

From the 16th century, British gentlemen wore loose, informal gowns in the privacy of the home as a comfortable alternative to the stiff and physically restrictive modes of dress required for public settings. This banyan is composed of a Chinese export silk quilted for warmth. // Banyan, Chinese, 1760–70; Alfred Z.Solomon-Janet A. Sloane Endowment Fund and Isabel Shults Fund, 2008 (2008.75). #TheMet #CostumeInstitute

L’Esprit Nouveau: Splendid examples of 1910s, 1920s, and 1930s evening wear—a particular strength of Sandy Schreier’s collection—embody l’esprit nouveau (“the modern spirit”) and express the vitality of the age. Characterized by innovative silhouettes and creative embellishment, these fashions attest to the superb capabilities of the specialist embroiderers, pleaters, and lace and flower makers operating at their height in advance of World War II. #TheMet #CostumeInsitute #InPursuitofFashion

While these thin knit gloves, designed by Elsa Schiaparelli, wouldn’t necessarily keep the wearer’s hands warm, they did make a statement. Gloves were a perfect manifestation of Schiaparelli's more avant-garde, Surrealist designs. This pair is decorated with gelatin discs reminiscent of chain mail armor or scales, and is both seductive and forbidding at the same time. // Gloves, Elsa Schiaparelli (Italian, 1890–1973), 1935–40; Brooklyn Museum Costume Collection at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, Gift of the Brooklyn Museum, 2009; Gift of Arturo and Paul Peralta-Ramos, 1954 (2009.300.1864a, b). #TheMet #CostumeInstitute

The Past Recaptured: For Sandy Schreier, an early stimulus for thinking about fashion as an art form came through regular childhood visits to the Detroit Institute of Arts, admiring dress and textiles depicted in paintings. This interest is represented by an array of designs by Mariano Fortuny y Madrazo and Maria Monaci Gallenga, both of whom worked in Italy in the early decades of the 20th century. Viewing themselves as artists, they approached dress from outside the traditional fashion system. Their fashions were initially most appreciated by individuals within the art world but grew to have broader appeal for their artfully designed fabrics and simple lines. #TheMet #CostumeInstitute #InPursuitofFashion

Ray of Light: This opulent, bright-coral Callot Soeurs dress from our collection is currently on view in the exhibition “French Fashion, Women, and the First World War” at The Bard Graduate Center Gallery. Though modesty and a somber palette are generally associated with French fashion created during World War I, this piece illustrates the fashion industry’s attempt to remain vital during a dark time. Here, a team of curators and conservators studied the intricate construction of the loan to ensure the dress could be safely and accurately displayed. // Dress, Callot Soeurs (French, active 1895–1937), 1915–16; Purchase, Irene Lewisohn Bequest, 1951 (C.I.51.97.1a, b) . #TheMet #CostumeInstitute

In Pursuit of Beauty: Sandy Schreier has described her initial approach to collecting as simply seeking beauty. However, her instinctive response to the objects she encountered in her early years was influenced by sources of inspiration that would continue to shape her approach, notably Hollywood film and her childhood introduction to fashion through Russeks, the Detroit specialty store where her father worked, and where she read Vogue and Harper’s Bazaar in the fitting rooms. #TheMet #CostumeInstitute #InPursuitofFashion

Yeohlee Teng’s designs show her interest in the structural possibilities of cloth. For this “Bellows” dress, she employs a silk lurex textile to create a form that indicates her spatial and temporal eye. The dress is both organic in its cocoon-like suppleness and futuristic in its industrial, high-tech gloss. // Dress, Yeohlee Teng (American, born Malaysia, 1951), fall/winter 2007–8; Gift of Yeohlee Teng, 2007 (2007.375.3) #TheMet #CostumeInstitute

#InPursuitofFashion opens today! Explore how pioneering collector Sandy Schreier assembled one of the finest private fashion collections in the United States, as seen through approximately 80 of her 165  promised gifts to @metmuseum. // Dress, Roberto Rojas (American, born 1940), 1967; Promised Gift of Sandy Schreier. #TheMet #CostumeInstitute

Dreams come true: Sandy Schreier visited @metmuseum as a teenager and dreamed of her collection being displayed here. Yesterday we celebrated the realization of her lifelong dream at the opening of #InPursuitofFashion showing 80 of the 165 objects in her promised gift to The #CostumeInstitute. // 📷: @BFA/Zach Hilty
First look at "In Pursuit of Fashion: The Sandy Schreier Collection." The exhibition opens this Wednesday and is on view through May 17, 2020. #TheMet #CostumeInstitute #InPursuitofFashion

#BTS: #FriendsofCostume recently visited The #CostumeInstitute’s Collections and Conservation Lab for a #behindthescenes peek. Our Friends group supports important acquisitions—our latest include an ensemble by Marc Jacobs, and Alexander McQueen’s iconic Armadillo shoes. // Ensemble, Marc Jacobs (American, born New York, 1963), spring/summer 2019; Purchase, Friends of The Costume Institute Gifts, 2019, (2019.154a–h). “Armadillo” Shoes, Alexander McQueen (British, 1969–2010) for Alexander McQueen (British, founded 1992), spring/summer 2010; Purchase, Friends of The Costume Institute Gifts, 2019 (2019.255a, b). #TheMet

In memoriam of Alexandra of Denmark (1844-November 20, 1925). Queen Alexandra was consort of King Edward VII (1841-1910) who reigned from 1901-1910. She was known as a fashionable trendsetter and in 1937, 12 years after her death, a selection of objects from her wardrobe were sold at auction in New York City. These are just a small selection of masterworks in our collection that were purchased at the auction by the founding members of The #CostumeInstitute. See more elegant fashions owned by Queen Alexandra by searching the collection on The Met’s website. // Dress, French, 1904; Gift of Miss Irene Lewisohn, 1937 (C.I.37.44.9a–d). Riding Ensemble, Morin Blossier, ca. 1905; Gift of Miss Irene Lewisohn, 1937 (C.I.37.44.3a, b). Evening dress, European, 1907; Rogers Fund, 1937 (37.94). Cap, British, 1901-11; Gift of Miss Irene Lewisohn, 1937 (C.I.37.44.4a, b). #TheMet

Polished! Sandy Schreier’s collection of accessories reflects the larger themes—like whimsy and playfulness—found throughout her entire collection. These gloves by Franco Moschino subvert the social propriety of gloves through an unsettling use of visible cosmetics. The tan leather amplifies the lifelike trompe l’oeil manicure. #InPursuitofFashion opens November 27. // Gloves, Franco Moschino (Italian, 1950–1994) for Moschino Couture (Italian, founded 1983), 1980s; Promised gift of Sandy Schreier.  Photo © Nicholas Alan Cope #TheMet #CostumeInstitute

Monkey Business: Glenn Petersen, Conservator, reduces the creases of this silk dress from Gilbert Adrian through careful application of steam. The conservators use a variety of remediation techniques to remove creases, with steaming only used if the garment is in strong and stable condition. See this dress on view #InPursuitofFashion, opening November 27. // Dress, Gilbert Adrian (American, 1903–1959), spring/summer 1950; promised gift of Sandy Schreier. #TheMet #CostumeInstitute

Mourning Josephus Thimister, who passed away this week. His fall/winter 2010–11 couture collection titled “Bloodshed and Opulence” was inspired by the Bolshevik Revolution and its aftermath. The collection alluded to the ravages of war through military-inspired ensembles which were shown in juxtaposition with designs that recalled the lost opulence of Imperial Russia, including this dress in our collection. The heavy beading lends weight to the fabric and structure to the silhouette, which is crowned with an integral, cowl-like hood. Thimister first introduced this silhouette in a series of garments designed for Balenciaga’s fall/winter 1996–97 ready-to-wear collection. The elegantly draped hoods evoked the face-framing veils of nun’s habits, an echo of Cristóbal Balenciaga’s lifelong referencing of ecclesiastical vestments. // Dress, Josephus Thimister (Dutch, 1962–2019), fall/winter 2010–11, edition 2017; Purchase, Friends of The Costume Institute Gifts, 2018 (2018.434). #TheMet #CostumeInstitute #FriendsofCostume
